citations.narrative:
The Program of Veterinary Care doesn't indicate how many dogs or what percentage of dogs must be sampled for
heartworm and fecal parasites. Not having the Program of Veterinary Care updated to include how many dogs need to be
sampled for parasites doesn't indicate to the licensee or the inspector how many dogs should be tested for these
parasites so the licensee is in compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. The Program of Veterinary Care needs to be
updated so the number of dogs that need to be tested for parasites is documented.

The licensee has informed me that the annual exams for all dogs are completed. In addition, the distemper and parvo
shots have been given and the HWT and fecal tests have been completed, but the licensee doesn't have any of the
documentation to show any of this has been done. Not having documentation that all of the above mentioned medical
procedures have been completed doesn't allow for the inspector to confirm that all these medical procedures have been
completed. The licensee must be able to provide records at inspection of all the medical procedures that have been
completed for all the dogs over the past year.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 8/13/23 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
End of report.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The Program of Veterinary Care doesn't indicate how many dogs or what percentage of dogs must be sampled for 
heartworm and fecal parasites. Not having the Program of Veterinary Care updated to include how many dogs need to be 
sampled for parasites doesn't indicate to the licensee or the inspector how many dogs should be tested for these 
parasites so the licensee is in compliance with the Animal Welfare Act. The Program of Veterinary Care needs to be 
updated so the number of dogs that need to be tested for parasites is documented. 
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee has informed me that the annual exams for all dogs are completed. In addition, the distemper and parvo 
shots have been given and the HWT and fecal tests have been completed, but the licensee doesn't have any of the 
documentation to show any of this has been done. Not having documentation that all of the above mentioned medical 
procedures have been completed doesn't allow for the inspector to confirm that all these medical procedures have been 
completed. The licensee must be able to provide records at inspection of all the medical procedures that have been 
completed for all the dogs over the past year. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 8/13/23 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
End of report. 
 
 n
